topic_or_construct: anticipatory positive affective reactions to risk
measured_by: Berlin Emotional Responses to Risk Instrument – BERRI-pos component
justification: “To create the scale scores, we averaged the scores … across the positive adjectives as a measure of positive affect (BERRI-pos).”

topic_or_construct: anticipatory negative affective reactions to risk
measured_by: Berlin Emotional Responses to Risk Instrument – BERRI-neg component
justification: “To create the scale scores, we averaged the scores across the negative adjectives as a measure of negative affect (BERRI-neg).”

measured_by: Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (PANAS) – Positive Affect subscale
justification: “Perhaps the most influential related instrument is the Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (PANAS)… The PANAS … has been successfully adapted for a very wide range of applications.”

measured_by: Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (PANAS) – Negative Affect subscale
justification: The same passage notes that PANAS provides assessment of both positive and negative affect, identifying it as a measure of negative affect as well.

“Another popular instrument is the self-assessment manikin (SAM), which is a nonverbal pictorial assessment that measures the estimated pleasure, arousal, and dominance associated with a person's subjective affective reaction.”
“Domain-specific risk-taking scale (DOSPERT) – This 30-item scale measures general risk-taking propensity in five different domains.”

topic_or_construct: Big Five personality dimensions (extraversion, agreeableness, conscientiousness, emotional stability, openness)
justification: “Ten-item personality inventory (TIPI) … used to assess extraversion, agreeableness, conscientiousness, emotional stability, and openness to experience.”

“The Berlin numeracy + Schwarz test (BNT-S) was administered, which is a test of practical probabilistic math skills that measures people's general ability to independently evaluate and understand risk (i.e., risk literacy).”
“Participants also indicated the amount of emotional distress they had felt in the past week using the Distress Thermometer from 1 (no distress at all) to 10 (extreme distress).”
